title: sourmash v4.6.0 breaks `sketch ... -o file.zip` with multiple ksizes
body:
```
sourmash sketch dna -p k=21,k=31,k=51,scaled=1000,abund podar-ref/1.fa -o /tmp/sig.zip
sourmash sig describe /tmp/sig.zip
```
yields only one ksize:
```
---
signature filename: /tmp/sig.zip
signature: ** no name **
source file: podar-ref/1.fa
md5: c55d50b7a3b860916f286a18de56e30b
k=21 molecule=DNA num=0 scaled=1000 seed=42 track_abundance=1
size: 1452
sum hashes: 1477
signature license: CC0

loaded 1 signatures total, from 1 files
```

title: `LCA_SqliteDatabase.select(...)` incorrectly returns a `SqliteIndex` object
body:
This incorrectly limits the return type functionality!

IMO the return from `SqliteIndex.select(...)` should construct the new object using `self.__class__` rather than `SqliteIndex`.

title: `sourmash_args._load_database` barfs on non-gzipped files with `.gz` extension
body:
discovered in tandem with https://github.com/sourmash-bio/sourmash/issues/2369,

```
cp ../sourmash/podar-ref/1.fa.sig ./xyz.gz
sourmash sig describe ./xyz.gz
```
raises a full on error message with `gzip.BadGzipFile` because of the manifest-loading code, which tries to open it as a .gz file and fails, but does NOT catch the exception and transform it into a `ValueError`.

title: sourmash sig extract missing some names
body:
I have a database `formatted_db.sig` that has inside it the following:
```
$sourmash sig describe formatted_db.sig
<snip>
signature filename: formatted_db.sig
signature: GCF_000174095.1_wUni_1.0_genomic.fna
source file: formatted_db.fasta
md5: cd7fc82579f3860d6f95a7943d6d8caf
k=31 molecule=DNA num=0 scaled=1000 seed=42 track_abundance=1
size: 809
sum hashes: 823
<snip>
```
So `GCF_000174095.1_wUni_1.0_genomic.fna` is certainly in there. However, `sourmash sig extract` can't find it:
```
$ sourmash sig extract --name GCF_000174095.1_wUni_1.fna formatted_db.sig

== This is sourmash version 4.5.0. ==
== Please cite Brown and Irber (2016), doi:10.21105/joss.00027. ==

loaded 1045 total that matched ksize & molecule type
no matching signatures to save!
```

title: check that reported `search` containment ani is using the right containment direction
body:
for @ctb -

If we're running `sourmash search`, are we producing the containment of the query in the reference, or the reference in the query? Thinking about it now I think we're doing query in the reference.

Over here https://github.com/sourmash-bio/sourmash/blob/latest/src/sourmash/search.py#L324, I think we're getting containment ANI relative to query (but using containment we generated during search), which would be wrong.

Generally, I think this is related to the syntax/meanings of `containment_ani` vs `contained_by`.

`self.contained_by(other)` = containment of self in other
`self.containment_ani` = ANI from containment of other in self

I think, besides fixing, it would probably be helpful to standardize the python api -- maybe `contained_by_to_ani`?

I think `prefetch` and `gather` results should be fine, because we generate containment, ani within those, so it was clear which direction to go.

title: panic bug in `MinHash.seq_to_hashes`
body:
I ran into a panic when working on doctests for #1695, but foolishly did not stop to save the exact code. I'm leaving it here so that @mr-eyes or I can return to it later to figure out what probably happened.

My guess is I provided too short a DNA sequence to  the method `seq_to_hashes` for a protein `MinHash`, but it's not trivial to replicate.

```
UNEXPECTED EXCEPTION: Panic()
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/Users/t/miniconda3/envs/py37/lib/python3.7/doctest.py", line 1329, in __run
    compileflags, 1), test.globs)
  File "<doctest api-example.md[68]>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/Users/t/dev/sourmash/src/sourmash/minhash.py", line 346, in kmers_and_hashes
    bad_kmers_as_zeroes=bad_kmers_as_zeroes)
  File "/Users/t/dev/sourmash/src/sourmash/minhash.py", line 317, in seq_to_hashes  
    hashes_ptr = self._methodcall(lib.kmerminhash_seq_to_hashes, to_bytes(sequence), len(sequence), force, bad_kmers_as_zeroes, is_protein, size)
  File "/Users/t/dev/sourmash/src/sourmash/utils.py", line 25, in _methodcall
    return rustcall(func, self._get_objptr(), *args)
  File "/Users/t/dev/sourmash/src/sourmash/utils.py", line 78, in rustcall
    raise exc
sourmash.exceptions.Panic: sourmash panicked: thread 'unnamed' panicked with 'removal index (is 0) should be < len (is 0)' at library/alloc/src/vec/mod.rs:1385
/Users/t/dev/sourmash/doc/api-example.md:284: UnexpectedException
```

title: Why is the idx reversed for fig labels but not for matrix reordering in fig.py?
body:
```
# re-order labels along rows, top to bottom
idx1 = Z1['leaves']
reordered_labels = [ labeltext[i] for i in reversed(idx1) ]
# reorder D by the clustering in the dendrogram
D = D[idx1, :]
D = D[:, idx1]
```
https://github.com/sourmash-bio/sourmash/blob/latest/src/sourmash/fig.py#L62

I was just trying to make a clustered heatmap for the output of `sourmash tax summarize --output-format lineage_summary` and I was reading the code for compare viz and saw that the label vector is reverse ordered based on `idx1`, but the comp matrix is reordered just based on `idx1` and i'm confused...wouldn't this  make it so that the labels and the matrix were in opposite order? like `1, 2, 3` and `3, 2, 1`?

title: Complete help text with `--help`?
body:
Using [this Dockerfile](https://github.com/nf-core/kmermaid/blob/master/Dockerfile), I'm unable to get the full help text with the descriptions so nicely written in [commands.py](https://github.com/dib-lab/sourmash/blob/master/sourmash/commands.py). No arguments, `-h` and `--help` all output the same help text, whereas I would expect `--help` to show the full description. Do you know why this is? Thank you!

```
(base) root@431eec5dfd0f:/home# sourmash compute -h
usage: sourmash [--protein] [--no-protein] [--dayhoff] [--no-dayhoff] [--dna]
                [--no-dna] [-q] [--input-is-protein] [-k KSIZES]
                [-n NUM_HASHES] [--check-sequence] [-f] [-o OUTPUT]

                [--license LICENSE]
                filenames [filenames ...]
sourmash: error: the following arguments are required: filenames

usage: sourmash [--protein] [--no-protein] [--dayhoff] [--no-dayhoff] [--dna]
                [--no-dna] [-q] [--input-is-protein] [-k KSIZES]
                [-n NUM_HASHES] [--check-sequence] [-f] [-o OUTPUT]
                [--singleton] [--merge MERGED] [--name-from-first]
                [--input-is-10x] [-p PROCESSES] [--track-abundance]
                [--scaled SCALED] [--seed SEED] [--randomize]
                [--license LICENSE]
                filenames [filenames ...]
sourmash: error: the following arguments are required: filenames
(base) root@431eec5dfd0f:/home# sourmash compute
usage: sourmash [--protein] [--no-protein] [--dayhoff] [--no-dayhoff] [--dna]
                [--no-dna] [-q] [--input-is-protein] [-k KSIZES]
                [-n NUM_HASHES] [--check-sequence] [-f] [-o OUTPUT]
                [--singleton] [--merge MERGED] [--name-from-first]
                [--input-is-10x] [-p PROCESSES] [--track-abundance]
                [--scaled SCALED] [--seed SEED] [--randomize]
                [--license LICENSE]
                filenames [filenames ...]
```

title: Setting "scaled=1" doesn't retrieve all protein k-mers
body:
Hi!

I was evaluating sourmash as a fast option to create signatures from the full k-mer set of single protein sequences. [According to the documentation](https://sourmash.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api-example.html#sourmash-minhash-objects-and-manipulations), setting `scaled=1` would retrieve all the k-mers of the input sequence.

However, in my tests I observed that the sketches were much smaller than I'd expect. Indeed, the number of hashes in the MinHash objects is much smaller than the real number of k-mers (the magnitude of this difference depends on the protein sequence).

[sourmash_protein_test.txt](https://github.com/dib-lab/sourmash/files/3415101/sourmash_protein_test.txt)

I'd expect this behavior for nucleotide sequences, due to canonical k-mers, but not for protein sequences. I don't think that hash collision would be causing this. I'm I missing something?

Thank you!

title: Fix memory leak in `MinHash.intersection`.
body:
The intersection function uses the `new` operator to construct
a `KmerMinHash` or `KmerMinAbundance`. Although this is Cython,
`new` still heap-allocates the object, and it is *not* marked
for garbage collection, because it isn't a PyObject. This commit
calls delete (`del`) on the allocated object to prevent it from
being leaked.

Addresses #685.

- [ ] Is it mergeable?
- [ ] `make test` Did it pass the tests?
- [ ] `make coverage` Is the new code covered?
- [ ] Did it change the command-line interface? Only additions are allowed
  without a major version increment. Changing file formats also requires a
  major version number increment.
- [ ] Was a spellchecker run on the source code and documentation after
  changes were made?

title: sourmash signature merge does not merge signatures
body:
I generated signatures from paired-end data like this:

```
rule calc_sigs_raw:
    output: "outputs/sigs/raw/{sample}_raw.sig"
    input:
        R1="inputs/SRA/{sample}_1.fastq.gz",
        R2="inputs/SRA/{sample}_2.fastq.gz"
    shell:'''
    sourmash compute -k 21,31,51 --scaled 2000 --track-abundance -o {output} {input.R1} {input.R2}
    '''
```
When I went to run gather, I realized this created 6 signatures (3 k sizes for each of R1 and R2). I decided to run `sourmash merge` on the k31 pieces to get one signature to run gather with:

```
rule merge_sigs_raw:
    output: "outputs/sigs/raw/{sample}_raw_merged.sig"
    input: "outputs/sigs/raw/{sample}_raw.sig"
    shell:'''
    sourmash signature merge -k 31 -o {output} {input}
    '''
```

And this output a signature with no hashes. Did I run this wrong, or is this an issue with `sourmash merge`? Can also confirm that this occurs outside of snakemake. Using sourmash version 2.0.0.

title: in sourmash index, --traverse-directory needs to go last -- it shouldn't
body:
Hi,

I struggled to get the `sourmash index --traverse-directory` arg working, mainly bc/ it needs to go last in the command line call, which is unintuitive given that it has a `--` prefix; or am I missing something?

```bash
# --traverse-directory like any command line arg
sourmash index --traverse-directory sigs/ -k 31 sbt_k31
loading 0 files into SBT

no signatures found to load into tree!? failing.

# --traverse-directory last
sourmash index -k 31 sbt_k31 --traverse-directory sigs/
loading 145817 files into SBT
...reading from sigs/RS_GCF_001393515.1_genomic.fna.sig (260 signatures so far)
```

Best,
Adrian

title: gather csv output column "filename" takes from first in list of databases
body: I recently ran sourmash gather with 5 databases simultaneously. The output csv file indicated in the `filename` column that each of my matches were from the first database that I listed, however they were from different databases that I listed.
